channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Turkish Leader Erdogan Making New Enemies and Frustrating Old Friends
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey spoke at a Ramadan feast at his palace last month in Ankara.
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan long professed a foreign policy of “zero problems with neighbors” but now seems mired in disputes with just about everybody.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Wigan’s Road to Brexit: Anger, Loss and Class Resentments
item.media:description: An English flag outside a house in a suburb of Wigan, a gritty northern English town where 64 percent of the population voted for “Brexit.”
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The Labour-dominated city voted Leave to jolt elites in London as well as in Brussels into restoring their lost world of secure jobs and communities.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Belgian Court Jails Islamic State Cell Leaders for Foiled Plot
item.media:description: Belgian judge Pierre Hendrickx, center, presides over the trial of suspects in the foiled terrorist plot in the town of Verviers last year, at the Brussels Palace of Justice in Belgium on Tuesday.
item.description: The plot’s chief architect in the thwarted Belgian plot was also the on-the-ground coordinator in the Paris attacks in November.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Suicide Bombings Hit 3 Cities in Saudi Arabia, One Near a Holy Site
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard near the United States Consulate in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, after a suicide bomber detonated explosives Monday morning.
item.description: The explosions, including near the Prophet’s Mosque in Medina, followed a bloody week of Islamic State attacks in other countries during Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Jewish Settlers, Attacked, Needed Help. A Palestinian Doctor Didn’t Hesitate.
item.media:description: Tehila Mark, left, at the funeral of her father, Rabbi Michael Mark, on Sunday. He was killed after a gunman fired on the family’s car in the West Bank. Tehila and her mother, Chavi, were also injured in the attack.
item.description: Dr. Ali Shroukh’s lifesaving efforts on a West Bank road have been hailed in Israel as inspirational in the face of months of increasing conflict.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Iraq Minister Resigns as Bombing Death Toll Reaches 175
item.description: The government minister largely responsible for security in Baghdad submitted his resignation Tuesday, two days after one of the biggest bombings in more than a decade of war and insurgency killed 175 people as the Muslim holy month of Ramadan came to an especially bloody conclusion.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Moves to Limit Protections for Its Civilian Military Workers in Japan
item.media:description: An activist waved a sign saying “Don’t Rape Okinawa,” as American personnel walked toward a United States Marine base on the island in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The preliminary deal follows a bout of public outrage over several crimes linked to personnel and contractors employed by the American armed forces.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Lightning Ridge Journal: An Australian Town’s Rare Mix: Dinosaur Bones and Opalized Pine Cones
item.media:description: Pete Cooke, right, sifting through rock, and his brother Mick Cooke mine for opals in Lightning Ridge, Australia.
item.media:credit: Conor Ashleigh for The New York Times
item.description: Lightning Ridge, a town on the edge of the outback, is hoping visitors will flock to see such treasures at a new museum expected to be completed by 2020.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Brazil Is Confronting an Epidemic of Anti-Gay Violence
item.media:description: Antonio Kvalo, 34, who created a website where Brazilians can log instances of anti-gay violence, said he had been motivated in part by his own experience.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: Despite a storied image as a tolerant, open society, Brazil is, by some counts, the world’s deadliest place for sexual minorities.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: From Refugee Chefs, a Taste of Home
item.media:description: A dish at L’Ami Jean.
item.media:credit: Corentin Fohlen for The New York Times
item.description: Two French entrepreneurs are using food to try to change perceptions of immigrants.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Swedish Police Investigate Over 40 Reports of Rape and Groping at 2 Music Festivals
item.media:description: A police officer at a Bravalla Festival campsite in Norrkoping, Sweden, last weekend.
item.media:credit: Izabelle Nordfjell/TT News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: Dozens of women and girls, most under the age of 18, said they were sexually assaulted at the Bravalla and Putte i Parken festivals over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: Welsh Reject E.U., but Its Money Will Be Missed
item.media:description: Economic difficulties are reflected by vacant storefronts and a proliferation of charity stores.
item.media:credit: Marco Kesseler for The New York Times
item.description: One of the looming questions in the aftermath of the “Brexit” vote is what happens to European Union aid flowing into places like Wales.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM

item.title: China Says Hong Kong Bookseller Must Return or Face Parole Violation Penalties
item.media:description: Lam Wing-kee was one of five Hong Kong booksellers who disappeared last year.
item.description: Lam Wing-kee, who went public about his monthslong detention in mainland China, was one of five men connected with Mighty Current Media who disappeared last year.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Conservative Backbiting; Labour Civil War; Welsh Regrets?
item.media:description: Home Secretary Theresa May in London on Tuesday. Ms. May has emerged as the clear front-runner among the five candidates seeking to replace David Cameron as leader of the Conservative Party.
item.description: A member of the Conservative Party was caught on camera sharing candid comments about his colleagues seeking the party’s leadership.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: French Inquiry Urges Changes to Intelligence Services in Light of Failures
item.description: Lawmakers who took part in the examination called on the authorities to merge overlapping and sometimes competing agencies.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Theresa May, the Steely, Steady Woman Who Might Lead Britain
item.media:description: Theresa May, the British home secretary and the front-runner to become Britain’s next prime minister, in London last week.
item.description: As lawmakers start voting to narrow the contenders for head of the party, Ms. May stands as a front-runner, with a reputation for seriousness and hard work behind her.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Rome Police Arrest Homeless Man in Murder of Beau Solomon, a U.S. Student
item.media:description: Forensic police officers scanned the banks of the Tiber in Rome where Beau Solomon’s body was found on Monday.
item.description: Mr. Solomon, of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, was found in the Tiber River with a head wound and blood on his shirt.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Nepal Investigating Indian Couple’s Claim of Climbing Everest
item.media:description: Satyarup Siddhanta, a climber based in Bangalore, India, holding in his right hand a photograph of him on Mount Everest, along with a version that he said an Indian couple had altered.
item.description: The couple are accused of doctoring photographs to suggest they reached the summit in May, becoming the first husband-and-wife team from India to do so.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere: Amid Floods in China, Stranded Pigs Are Thrown a Lifeline
item.media:description: Li Zuming, a worker at a pig farm in Anhui Province, cried on Monday as he waded through floodwaters that threatened to engulf thousands of pigs.
item.description: Some of the thousands of swine that appeared destined for a watery end were rescued when a city’s government mobilized workers to help relocate them.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Ikea Under Fire in China After Limiting Dresser Recall to North America
item.media:description: Chinese shoppers trying out the merchandise at an Ikea store in Beijing.
item.description: The chests and dressers that are being recalled have been linked to the deaths of at least six children in the United States and Canada.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG

item.title: Sinosphere: China Cracks Down on News Reports Spread via Social Media
item.media:description: A villager in Sichuan Province reading his mobile phone. The government said it would punish websites that publish “directly as news reports unverified content found on online platforms such as social media.”
item.description: The Cyberspace Administration said it would punish sites that publish “directly as news reports unverified content found on online platforms,” but others see an effort to clamp down.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and VANESSA PIAO

item.title: Berlusconi Leaves Hospital Weak, Hopes to Still Help Italy
item.description: Ex-Italian Premier Silvio Berlusconi left a hospital Tuesday three weeks after undergoing heart surgery, saying he hopes to still be useful to Italians but lamenting the current state of Italy, Europe and the world.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: After a Year, Rohingya Family Still Separated and Stranded
item.media:description: Hasinah Izhar performing a midday prayer last month in her family’s rented room in Penang, Malaysia.
item.media:credit: Rahman Roslan for The New York Times
item.description: Little has changed since an anguished mother told of fleeing Myanmar to seek refuge in Malaysia, with three children in tow — and one left behind.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)

item.title: Michel Rocard, Former Prime Minister of France, Dies at 85
item.media:description: Michel Rocard, left, the prime minister of France, in 1990 with President Francois Mitterrand, his longtime political rival.
item.description: The politician was known for his efforts as a pragmatic reformer of the Socialist Party and for his struggles with President François Mitterrand.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Britain’s Role in Iraq War: What to Expect From Chilcot Report
item.media:description: British soldiers on patrol in Iraq in 2007. The Iraq Inquiry Committee, or the Chilcot inquiry, will release a 12-volume report on Britain’s role in the Iraq war.
item.media:credit: Marko Georgiev for The New York Times
item.description: The seven-year investigation by the Iraq Inquiry Committee, known as the Chilcot inquiry, lasted longer than British combat operations in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: South Korea Targets Executives, Pressed by an Angry Public
item.media:description: John Lee, a former chief executive of the South Korean unit of Reckitt Benckiser, was taken in for questioning by prosecutors in Seoul in May.
item.description: Long seen as lenient on businesses, South Korea is increasingly seeking to prosecute company officials to address public anger over corporate misbehavior.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: ISIS Bombing in Baghdad Casts Doubt on Iraqi Leader’s Ability to Unite
item.media:description: People gathered on Sunday at the scene of a car bombing that killed more than 150 people in Karrada, a busy shopping district in Baghdad.
item.description: After at least 155 people were killed in a car bombing in Baghdad, Iraq’s leader tried to assuage the public’s anger and grief by speeding the executions of militants.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: After Attacks, Lebanese Christian Town Casts Wary Eye on Syrian Refugees
item.media:description: A young Christian at the funeral of a relative killed in a suicide attack in Al Qaa, Lebanon, last week. Last Monday, two waves of suicide bombers blew themselves up in the village, leaving five men dead and wounding dozens.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: A wave of deadly suicide bombings in the quiet town of Al Qaa has strained a tenuous coexistence between residents and newcomers fleeing Syria’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Letter From Europe: Chaotic Building Spree Dismays Some in Seaside Georgian City
item.media:description: The architectural ambitions of former President Mikheil Saakashviliv of Georgia were seemingly unlimited, especially in Batumi, which he hoped to turn into a vacation destination.
item.description: A former president’s determination to give Georgia a more contemporary look has left Batumi’s skyline a bizarre mash-up of architectural styles.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Malaysia Links Nightclub Attack to Islamic State
item.media:description: Forensic specialists investigating the explosion at a nightclub in Puchong, Malaysia, late last month that the authorities now believe was the work of Islamic State.
item.description: The episode, which wounded eight people in Puchong, was thought to have been the first assault in Malaysia tied to the militant group.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Memo From Jerusalem: Israelis’ Favorite Thing About Donald Trump? His Style (to Put It Bluntly)
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, at a campaign event in Dallas last month.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: While Israelis have mixed views of Mr. Trump’s policy proposals, they admiringly describe him as “dugri,” a slang Hebrew term derived from the Arabic for “straight ahead.”
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Australian Candidates Woo Allies as Election Deadlock Continues
item.media:description: Voters waited to cast their ballots in Bondi Beach, near Sydney, Australia, over the weekend.
item.description: Neither the governing Liberal National coalition nor the Labor Party won enough seats outright to form a government.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Conservative Mudslinging, and George Osborne Calls for Tax Cuts
item.media:description: Thousands demonstrated in London on Saturday against a British exit from the European Union.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Michael Gove was criticized as having an “emotional need to gossip,” and Mr. Osborne said that he wanted to reduce Britain’s corporate tax to 15 percent.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: Ling Jihua, Ex-Presidential Aide in China, Gets Life Sentence for Corruption
item.media:description: Ling Jihua, once a top aide to former President Hu Jintao, in 2013. He joined two other notable senior party officials in receiving a lifetime prison sentence for graft.
item.description: Mr. Ling joins two other notable senior party officials in receiving a lifetime prison sentence for graft.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Nigel Farage, Who Spurred ‘Brexit,’ Resigns as Head of U.K. Independence Party
item.description: Mr. Farage, the politician who probably did more than any other to force the referendum on British membership in the European Union, resigned on Monday.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu Traces Path to Power Back to Entebbe, and Lost Brother
item.media:description: Mr. Netanyahu and President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda during the ceremony on Monday.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke at an airport in Uganda 40 years after a daring raid there killed his brother and propelled him into politics.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sex May Spread Zika Virus More Often Than Researchers Suspected
item.media:description: A couple in Rio de Janeiro last year. Intimate contact may account for more Zika infections than previously suspected, though recent findings have been disputed.
item.description: It’s not just mosquitoes: Two reports suggest that women in South America, especially of childbearing age, are likelier to be infected than men.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: What in the World: The Lab Results Are In: Genes Might Be to Blame for Retrievers’ Obesity
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lia Kantrowitz; photographs by Africa Studio, Best photo studio, Petr Salinger, Phich Keers, Hurst Photo, Dojdis, stockcreations/Shutterstock
item.description: Labrador retrievers’ renowned gluttony and resulting obesity may be due to a faulty gene that regulates appetite and helps sense how much fat is stored.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: What in the World: Proud to Live in a Town Called Dildo
item.description: Residents of Dildo, Newfoundland, are eager to dispel misguided notions about where their town got its name.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: How Do You Say ‘Welcome to Europe’ in Maltese? Check an Arabic Dictionary
item.description: About a third of the words, not to mention the language’s grammar, are derived from the Arabic that was spoken by Muslim settlers of the Mediterranean islands.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Editorial: Fighting ISIS as It Shifts Tactics
item.description: The threat requires a complex response, including better cooperation among the region’s nations and the United States.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Contributing Opinion Writer: After Brexit, Can Germany Lead Europe Alone?
item.description: The British exit from the E.U. has put Angela Merkel and her colleagues in a tough position amid nationalistic shifts on the Continent.
item.dc:creator: ANNA SAUERBREY

item.title: Editorial: Don’t Let Iran’s Progress on the Nuclear Deal Go to Waste
item.description: It’s important that Iran benefit from meeting its commitments, though there can be no complacency.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
